div.p: This paper establishes a framework for robust stability analysis of linear time-invariant uncertain systems. The uncertainty is assumed to belong to an arbitrary subset of complex matrices. The concept used here is well-posedness of feedback systems, leading to necessary and sufficient conditions for robust stability. Based on this concept, some insights into exact robust stability conditions are given. In particular, frequency domain and state-space conditions for well-posedness are provided in terms of Hermitian-form inequalities. It is shown that these inequalities can be interpreted as small-gain conditions with a generalized class of scalings given by linear fractional transformations (LFT's). Using the LFT-scaled small-gain condition in the state-space setting, the "duality" is established between the H1 norm condition with frequency-dependent scalings and the parameter-dependent Lyapunov condition. Connections to the existing results, including the structured singular value and the integral quadratic constraints, are also discussed. Finally, we show that our well-posedness conditions can be used to give a less conservative, yet computable bound on the real structured singular value. This result is illustrated by numerical examples.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: T HE OBJECTIVE of robust stability analysis is to deter- mine whether or not a given uncertain system is stable for all possible uncertainties. A standard approach is to "pull out" the uncertain component of the system, identify the known component as the nominal part, and express the uncertain system as the feedback connection of and . In this way, it becomes clear how the uncertainties enter the system and what properties they have (e.g., norm-boundedness). The former information is embedded in and the latter is formalized as the set of possible uncertainties . Then, the problem is, given and , to find a verifiable condition under which the feedback system is stable for all . A useful concept for robust stability analysis is wellposedness of feedback systems; the uncertain system described by the feedback connection of and is robustly stable if and only if the feedback system is well posed1 for all . This concept has been exploited for robustness analysis with respect to the norm-bounded structured uncertainty [1], [2]; the structured singular value is defined such that gives a necessary and sufficient condition for the feedback system to be well posed for all possible uncertainties. The computation of is extremely difficult [3], and hence a more tractable small-gain condition with a diagonal scaling ( -scaling) is often used as an upper bound for [1], [4]. Unfortunately, the robust stability test involving the -scaling is known to be conservative in general [2].

As an extension to the -scaling approach, the notion of the linear fractional transformation (LFT)-scaling has been introduced [5] where the nominal plant is "scaled" by LFT. The robust stability test based on the LFT-scaling is better than the -scaling (or -scaling [6] for real parametric uncertainty) test in the sense that the scaling parameter space is larger, and hence the test is less conservative. Other interesting results in this direction include that of Fu and Barabanov [7] where an upper bound for is given using a multiplier technique and is shown to be better (less conservative) than the bound given by -scaling. However, these new tests can still fail even if the system being tested is robustly stable, i.e., they are conservative.

Another important concept behind robust stability is the notion of topological separation [8]- [10]; the system is robustly stable if and only if the graph of and the inverse graph of are topologically separated for all . Recent results by Goh and Safonov [11] showed that the integral quadratic constraint (IQC) condition for robust stability [12], [13] can be interpreted in terms of the topological separation view point. That is, topological separation (and hence robust stability) of the feedback system can be established by searching for an appropriate symmetric matrix (which we call "quadratic separator") used for the quadratic form in the IQC condition. While the existence of a quadratic separator is sufficient to conclude robust stability, its necessity is not clear for the general class of uncertainties .

The main objective of this paper is to provide a framework for robust stability analysis of uncertain systems described by the feedback connection of and , based on the concept of well-posedness. Necessary and sufficient robust stability conditions are developed in a very general setting; the properties (structure, norm-boundedness, etc.) of are not specified concretely, allowing for to be an arbitrary subset of complex matrices. It appears to be computationally difficult to verify the exact robust stability conditions presented in this paper. In fact, we do not expect the existence of efficient algorithms to verify these conditions, for the exact analysis has been proven to be extremely difficult (e.g., [3]). Nevertheless, our results provide some insights into the exact analysis problem, showing the connections among , IQC, conic sector analysis, scaled small-gain conditions, and parameter-dependent Lyapunov conditions.

In particular, frequency domain and state-space conditions for well-posedness are provided in terms of Hermitian-form inequalities. These conditions give an exact characterization of for the special case where the uncertainty is the set of norm-bounded block diagonal matrices. It turned out that the frequency domain condition is exactly the IQC condition [12] for robust stability, while the state-space condition differs from the corresponding state-space IQC condition obtained through Kalman-Yakubovich-Popov lemma (e.g., [14]). It is shown, using the topological separation property of IQC's [11], that our conditions can be interpreted as small-gain conditions with a generalized class of scalings given by LFT's. Using the LFT-scaled small-gain condition in the state-space setting, the "duality" is established between the norm condition with frequency-dependent scalings and the parameter-dependent Lyapunov condition.

Although it is nontrivial to solve our exact robust stability conditions, our results also have practical implications. Namely, our results may be used as a basis for obtaining computationally tractable upper and lower bounds on certain stability margins. We will give a general idea of how to "approximate" our exact condition to find such bounds. As applications of this idea, the notions of the -separator and the vertex-separator are introduced to give sufficient conditions for robust stability (and hence a lower bounds on the stability margin). The -separator is "equivalent" to the -scaling in terms of conservativeness but allows for more flexibility and uniformity in robustness analysis. The vertex-separator provides a bound on the real which is less conservative than the existing bounds, at the expense of more computation. For both separators, the resulting computational problems are given in terms of linear matrix inequalities (LMI's) [15], [16] and can be solved numerically [17], [18].
This work is motivated by the result of [5]. Conference versions of the present paper have appeared in [19] and [20].

Recall that the -scaling is known to be conservative, and restricting the class of the -scaling to be finite-dimensional linear time-invariant (FDLTI) systems may introduce extra conservatism. In contrast, Theorem 4 shows that the norm conditions scaled by the LFT's on the nominal plant and the uncertainty provide a necessary and sufficient condition for robust stability. Although this is a new result in a theoretical sense, the question of how this fact can be useful for computation still remains open.

div.head: C. Further Discussions
div.p: The idea behind the proof of Theorem 4 is to consider the condition in Fig. 4(a) with the special choice , where is the frequency variable and is the uncertain parameter, and pull down into to get a frequency dependent LFT-scaling [see Fig. 5(a)]. The "dual" formulation is also possible; we may pull down instead of into , to get a parameter-dependent LFT-scaling [Fig. 5(b)]. In this case, the resulting robust stability condition involving may be interpreted in terms of the parameter-dependent Lyapunov function, where the Lyapunov matrix depends on the parameter in a linear fractional manner. Again, our result shows that this restriction of parameter-dependence does not introduce conservatism.

The state-space IQC formulation [12] derived via the Kalman-Yakubovich-Popov lemma provides a computationally tractable sufficient condition for robust stability. This condition may be interpreted as a generalization of the condition with the frequency-dependent scaling which is parameterized by basis functions. As the authors state there, however, this approach does not show the relationship between the parameter-dependent Lyapunov functions and the IQC-type analysis. On the other hand, the well-posedness condition in Corollary 1 may be thought of as a new formulation of the state-space IQC condition, and based on this result Theorem 3 establishes a connection between the parameter-dependent Lyapunov condition and the scaled condition for robust stability. In the next section, we address the computational aspect of verifying statement 2) of Corollary 1.
Finally, we point out that similar results to those in Theorems 3 and 4 may be developed in the positive real setting with generalized multiplier.

div.p: The choice for presented in this section is a generalization of the -scaling; the class of we consider for this case is a subset of block diagonal complex matrices with each block satisfying a sector condition. This class of can be transformed (with a mild assumption) to the class of "norm-bounded uncertainties," and therefore the -scaling is applicable. The set we propose, the -separator, is obtainable by transforming the -scaling and thus they are essentially "equivalent." While the -separator does not go beyond the -scaling in terms of conservativeness, it provides a way for directly treating sector-bounded "uncertainties" including the passive and norm-bounded uncertainties as well as the continuous/discrete-time systems.

div.head: V. CONCLUSION
div.p: A framework is established for robust stability analysis, based on the well-posedness of feedback systems. Several forms of exact (nonconservative) robust stability conditions are derived. Insights into the exact analysis are given in comparison with the existing results including those from the and the IQC analysis methods. In particular, the duality relationship is established between the scaled condition with frequencydependent scaling and the parameter-dependent Lyapunov functions. Conceptual guidelines are given for tractable approximate computations in a general setting.
